column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=DESCRIPTION OF RELATED ART
#Text=[0001] A flat iron is a useful home appliance for pressing wrinkled fabrics.
#Text=However, a problem occurs if a hot flat iron is left resting on a piece of fabric.
#Text=The fabric may be damaged or even set on fire.
#Text=A piece of fabric that catches fire represents a danger to both people and property.
#Text=[0002] One existing solution is to use a timer.
#Text=To use the iron, the timer must be set.
#Text=When the timer expires, the iron shuts off until the timer is set again.
#Text=A disadvantage of this solution is that a short timeout period provides increasing safety but it is also inconvenient because the timer must be reset often.
#Text=If a long timeout period is used, the iron may rest on a piece of fabric for a long time before shutting off and therefore cause damage to the fabric or even a fire.
#Text=[0003] Another existing solution is to use a motion sensor.

#Text=However, a single motion sensor in an iron cannot determine both the motion of the iron and the orientation of the iron (e.g., determining if the iron is sitting flat against a surface or on its heel and away from the surface).
#Text=Thus, both a motion sensor and a tilt sensor would have to be used, thereby increasing the cost of the iron.
#Text=Some motion sensors also use a mercury tilt switch, which is difficult to dispose after the useful life of the iron.
#Text=[0004] Yet another existing solution is an iron that uses only steam.

#Text=As the temperature of steam is below the ignition temperature of most fabrics, such an iron will not cause fabric to catch fire even if it is left in contact with the fabric for an extended period of time.
#Text=A disadvantage of this solution is that a steam-only iron does not remove wrinkles as well as a conventional flat iron.
